Award.AwardTitle: 2015 Fifth Annual Mid-Atlantic Regional Mathematics Student Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the Fifth Annual Mid-Atlantic Regional Joint Mathematics Conference, held at George Mason University, March 20-21, 2015. The goals of the conference are to (a) bring together students and experts in industry and academia; (b) provide undergraduate and graduate students as well as post-doctoral associates and new doctoral degree holders an opportunity to present their research in a professional conference setting; (c) foster interdisciplinary collaboration among research groups from both academia and industry; (d) encourage networking between students and industry professionals and; (e) increase student awareness of, and interest in, U.S. government and private industry careers. This conference will strengthen the connection between mathematical advances in industry, government agencies, and academia. Professionals from industry and government agencies, academicians, and students will benefit from the diverse collection of talks, focusing on real world problems as well as recent theoretical advances. The core participating universities for this conference are George Mason University, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, and Shippensburg University.

The conference will focus on recent advances in applied mathematics, including optimal control theory, partial differential equations and the finite element method, computational topology, probability theory and stochastic processes, fluid dynamics, the modeling of materials, and machine learning. Additionally, the conference will feature talks concerning traditionally pure and applied areas of mathematics with emphasis on computational aspects of problem solving as well as education. The conference will help to prepare mathematical sciences students for careers in business, industry, and government. Industry participants will benefit from learning about cutting-edge academic advances and from access to highly-trained problem solvers, and students will benefit from exposure to real world problems, thus giving context to their areas of study. The broader impact of the conference is the increased collaboration between industry, government and academia. By bringing these diverse groups together, the meeting will foster the exchange of ideas on how to tackle new, complex problems. Additionally, the conference provides young academic researchers a chance to network with industry professionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 Fifth Annual SIAM Mid-Atlantic Regional Mathematical Student Conference and Industrial Day was hosted at George Mason University, March 20-21, 2015. This conference was co-organized by George Mason University, Virginia Tech and Shippensburg University with partnering institutions that are in the mid-Atlantic for students and faculty to be able to travel to Northern Virginia.

The conference was able to attract 75 participants from over 10 institutions that included students at all levels and faculty. It included over 30 student talks, a panel session by members of the industry, a plenary session by a distinguished faculty member and information sharing session on the gradaute research fellowship programs. The conference was able to achieve the proposed goals including bringing together students and experts in industry and academia; providing undergraduate and graduate students as well as post-doctoral, new PhD degree holders and junior faculty an opportunity to present their research in a similar setting to prefessional conference such as SIAM, MAA and AMS meetings; fostering intedisciplinary collaboration with research groups from both academia and industry; encouraging networking between students and industry professionals and; increasing student awareness of and interest in U.S. Government and private industry careers. The conference helped to promote the goals of the National Science Foundation that acts as a catalyst for preparing mathematical sciences students for Business, Industry, and Government (BIG). To forward this agenda, the conference focussed on recent advances in applied mathematics, including optimal control theory, partial differential equations and the finite element method, computational topology, probability theory and stochastic processes, fluid dynamics, the modeling of materials, and machine learning. Additionally, the conference was able to feature talks concerning traditionally pure and applied areas of mathematics with emphasis on computational aspects of problem solving as well as education.

The broader impact of this conference is that it increased collaboration between industry, government and academia. By bringing these diverse groups together, the conference was able to foster the exchange of ideas on how to tackle new, complex problems. Additionally, the conference helped to provide an opportunity for students to practice giving talks in a professional setting and a chance to network with industry professionals who may offer avenues for future careers. Through the participation of industry, we were able to increase the awareness of the application of mathematical techniques and computational mathematics to real world problem. The conference also provide a forum for the next generation STEM workforce including women and underrepresented minorities to learn about new research venues that can help them consider pursuing a career in mathematical sciences.
